instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that only powers on with the SMC reset key combination. Otherwise, it tries to power on, reaches 0.545 A, fan spin for a few seconds, but then powers off and stays at 0.030 A.

Is this a known issue? Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Check <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> voltages and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I've tested with the board alone, and it didn't power on.

I've checked it again, and I saw that <RESISTOR>R5177</RESISTOR> was a bit corroded, and so I ireplaced. After the replacement of <RESISTOR>R5177</RESISTOR>, the board started to power on, but on the first boot, it died on the Apple logo (the screen turned black), and now it seams that it powers on, but I have no image (internal or external).

I have fan spin, voltages on all big coils, CPU gets hot, but I have no USB activity.

I think that it might be a BIOS problem. Is there any way for me to confirm that, before desoldering it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You have some time dealing with Apple boards; Medusa programmer is a MUST have!

I suspect something more affected by corrosion.
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and traces.
Also clean J6100.

As basic rule, reball SMC when found corrosion near to it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi again,

I do have a medusa (by your sugestion; tks), but I already have made with medusa a clean ME, Check if SPI signals are controllable, Fix checksum of Fsys block, and forced a PRAM clean, but with no success.

I thought that I needed to flash the BIOS. Is there any thing else that I can do with medusa in these cases?

I'm going to check the  SPI Bus Termination resistors and traces and reball SMC, and post the result here.

Tks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

After reballing the SMC the mac didn't power on at all.

I've replaced the SMC, and now it works fine. You're right. It was a bad SMC. TKS.

Are there any other tests that I can do with the medusa in those cases? Were the procedures that I've made with the medusa correct?  Does the medusa " Check if SPI signals are controllable " checks that the values of the  SPI Bus Termination resistors values and if traces are OK, or does this check other thing?

TKS!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
If there is broken trace/resistor between SPI chip and J6100, Medusa can't work properly.
But you still need to check the resistors and traces from <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to SMC and PCH.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
